bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Leslie W. Weedon, May 12, 1919

div1.p: Carter writes that a mosquito eradication campaign should be started in the ports along the Gulf of Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Leslie W. Weedon, May 12, 1919
div1.opener:
Missc
Y. F.
Weeden
May 12, 1919.
Dr. Leslie Weeden,
2nd Floor, Am. National Bank Bldg.
Tampa, Fla.
Dear Doctor Weeden:
div1.p:
In answer to both of your letters of April
12 and 14, I would say that it is extremely advisable that
all Ports in the United States in which the stegomyia prevail
to such an extent as to be capable of spreading Yellow Fever
rid themselves of this mosquito. It is especially advisable
for the Gulf Ports as they are closer to the sources of in-
fection.

It is easy to do this. It simply requires
control of water in artificial containers and it would pay
many folds from a pecuniary standpoint because if worthy meas-
ures are carried out quarantine for Yellow Fever would be un-
necessary for these places, naturally it would be also much
safer.

I have written an article on Yellow Fever
which is to come out in an English system of Tropical Medi-
cine, in which this measure of rendering quarantine both
safer and unnecessary is gone into in as much detail as my
space allowed. If they give me some of the “Author's copies”
I will send you one. I think the same thing is advocated
in a lecture of mine on Yellow Fever published some years
ago. If it is on file here I will send it to you.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
